text: Find the co-factors of the elements of the matrix: $\begin{pmatrix} -1 & 2 \\ -3 & 4 \end{pmatrix}$
Find the co-factors of the elements of the matrix: $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & -1 & 2 \\ -2 & 3 & 5 \\ -2 & 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}$
answer:
Let the given matrix be $A$. The co-factor $A_{ij} = (-1)^{i+j}M_{ij}$.
$A_{11} = (-1)^{1+1} \begin{vmatrix} 3 & 5 \\ 0 & -1 \end{vmatrix} = -3$.
$A_{12} = (-1)^{1+2} \begin{vmatrix} -2 & 5 \\ -2 & -1 \end{vmatrix} = -12$.
$A_{13} = (-1)^{1+3} \begin{vmatrix} -2 & 3 \\ -2 & 0 \end{vmatrix} = 6$.
$A_{21} = (-1)^{2+1} \begin{vmatrix} -1 & 2 \\ 0 & -1 \end{vmatrix} = -1$.
$A_{22} = (-1)^{2+2} \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ -2 & -1 \end{vmatrix} = 3$.
$A_{23} = (-1)^{2+3} \begin{vmatrix} 1 & -1 \\ -2 & 0 \end{vmatrix} = 2$.
$A_{31} = (-1)^{3+1} \begin{vmatrix} -1 & 2 \\ 3 & 5 \end{vmatrix} = -11$.
$A_{32} = (-1)^{3+2} \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ -2 & 5 \end{vmatrix} = -9$.
$A_{33} = (-1)^{3+3} \begin{vmatrix} 1 & -1 \\ -2 & 3 \end{vmatrix} = 1$.

text: Find the matrix of co-factors for the matrix: $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 \\ 4 & -1 \end{pmatrix}$
answer: Let the given matrix be $A$. The co-factors are $A_{11} = -1$, $A_{12} = -4$, $A_{21} = -3$, $A_{22} = 1$. The matrix of co-factors is $\begin{pmatrix} -1 & -4 \\ -3 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: Find the matrix of co-factors for the matrix: $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 2 \\ -2 & 1 & 3 \\ 0 & 3 & -5 \end{pmatrix}$
Find the adjoint of the matrix: $\begin{pmatrix} 2 & -3 \\ 3 & 5 \end{pmatrix}$ (HSC Textbook)
answer: Let $A = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -3 \\ 3 & 5 \end{pmatrix}$. First, find the matrix of co-factors: $\begin{pmatrix} 5 & -3 \\ 3 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$. The adjoint of A, adj(A), is the transpose of the co-factor matrix. adj(A) = $\begin{pmatrix} 5 & 3 \\ -3 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: If $A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & -1 & 2 \\ 3 & 0 & -2 \\ 1 & 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$, verify that $A(\text{adj } A) = (\text{adj } A)A = |A|I$. (March 2017)
answer:
$|A| = 1(0 - 0) - (-1)(9 - (-2)) + 2(0 - 0) = 11$. The matrix of co-factors is $\begin{pmatrix} 0 & -11 & 0 \\ 3 & 1 & -1 \\ 2 & 8 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$. adj(A) = $\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 & 2 \\ -11 & 1 & 8 \\ 0 & -1 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$.
$A(\text{adj } A) = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & -1 & 2 \\ 3 & 0 & -2 \\ 1 & 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 & 2 \\ -11 & 1 & 8 \\ 0 & -1 & 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 11 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 11 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 11 \end{pmatrix} = 11I$. Similarly, $(\text{adj } A)A = 11I$. The property is verified.

text: Find the inverse of the matrix $\begin{pmatrix} 2 & -2 \\ 4 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$ by the adjoint method.
answer: Let $A = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -2 \\ 4 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$. $|A| = (2)(3) - (-2)(4) = 14$. The adjoint is adj(A) = $\begin{pmatrix} 3 & 2 \\ -4 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$. The inverse is $A^{-1} = \frac{1}{14} \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 2 \\ -4 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: Find the inverse of the matrix $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 0 & 2 & 4 \\ 0 & 0 & 5 \end{pmatrix}$ by the adjoint method.
answer: Let $A$ be the matrix. Since it's an upper triangular matrix, its determinant is the product of the diagonal elements: $|A| = (1)(2)(5) = 10$. The co-factor matrix is $\begin{pmatrix} 10 & 0 & 0 \\ -10 & 5 & 0 \\ 2 & -4 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$. The adjoint is the transpose: adj(A) = $\begin{pmatrix} 10 & -10 & 2 \\ 0 & 5 & -4 \\ 0 & 0 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$. The inverse is $A^{-1} = \frac{1}{10} \begin{pmatrix} 10 & -10 & 2 \\ 0 & 5 & -4 \\ 0 & 0 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: Find the inverse of the matrix $\begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0 & -1 \\ 5 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$ by elementary row transformations. (July 2017)
answer: Start with $[A|I]$. $\left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc} 2 & 0 & -1 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 5 & 1 & 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 3 & 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array} \right]$. Apply $R_1 \leftrightarrow R_2$, then $R_2 \to R_2 - 2R_1$. Continue row operations to get $[I|A^{-1}]$. The result is $A^{-1} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -1 & 1 \\ -15 & 6 & -5 \\ 5 & -2 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: If $A = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 1 & 3 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$, then reduce it to $I_3$ by using row transformations.
answer: Given $A$. Apply $R_1 \leftrightarrow R_2$ to get $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 & 3 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$. Then apply $R_2 \rightarrow R_2 - 2R_1$ and $R_3 \rightarrow R_3 - R_1$ to get $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$. Apply $R_3 \rightarrow R_3 - R_2$ to get $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}$. Apply $R_3 \rightarrow -R_3$. Finally, apply $R_1 \rightarrow R_1 - R_3$ and $R_2 \rightarrow R_2 - R_3$ to get $I_3$.

text: Check whether the matrix $\begin{pmatrix} \cos\theta & \sin\theta \\ -\sin\theta & \cos\theta \end{pmatrix}$ is invertible or not.
answer: A matrix is invertible if its determinant is non-zero. Let $A$ be the matrix. $|A| = (\cos\theta)(\cos\theta) - (\sin\theta)(-\sin\theta) = \cos^2\theta + \sin^2\theta = 1$. Since $|A| = 1 \neq 0$, the matrix is invertible.

text: Find AB, if $A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 1 & -2 & -3 \end{pmatrix}$ and $B = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & -1 \\ 1 & 2 \\ 1 & -2 \end{pmatrix}$. Examine whether AB has an inverse or not.
answer: $AB = \begin{pmatrix} 1(1)+2(1)+3(1) & 1(-1)+2(2)+3(-2) \\ 1(1)-2(1)-3(1) & 1(-1)-2(2)-3(-2) \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 6 & -3 \\ -4 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$. The determinant is $|AB| = (6)(1) - (-3)(-4) = 6 - 12 = -6$. Since $|AB| \neq 0$, the matrix AB has an inverse.

text: If $A = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 5 \\ 2 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$, then show that $A^{-1} = \frac{1}{6}(5I-A)$.
answer: There appears to be a typo in the question. It should likely be $A^{-1} = \frac{1}{-6}(A-5I)$. Let's prove that. LHS: $|A| = 4-10=-6$. $A^{-1} = \frac{1}{-6}\begin{pmatrix} 1 & -5 \\ -2 & 4 \end{pmatrix}$. RHS: $A-5I = \begin{pmatrix} 4-5 & 5 \\ 2 & 1-5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 5 \\ 2 & -4 \end{pmatrix}$. So $\frac{1}{-6}(A-5I) = \frac{1}{-6}\begin{pmatrix} -1 & 5 \\ 2 & -4 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{1}{6}\begin{pmatrix} 1 & -5 \\ -2 & 4 \end{pmatrix}$. The equation as written in the question is incorrect.

text: Find matrix X such that $AX=B$, where $A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ -1 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$ and $B = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 4 \end{pmatrix}$.
answer: $X = A^{-1}B$. First find $A^{-1}$. $|A| = 3 - (-2) = 5$. $A^{-1} = \frac{1}{5}\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -2 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$. Then $X = \frac{1}{5}\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -2 \\ 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 2 & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{1}{5}\begin{pmatrix} -4 & -5 \\ 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -4/5 & -1 \\ 2/5 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: Find X, if $AX=B$ where $A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ -1 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 4 \end{pmatrix}$ and $B = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$.
answer: $X = A^{-1}B$. First find $A^{-1}$. $|A|=3$. adj(A) = $\begin{pmatrix} 0 & -2 & 1 \\ 6 & 1 & -5 \\ -3 & 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$. $A^{-1} = \frac{1}{3} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & -2 & 1 \\ 6 & 1 & -5 \\ -3 & 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$. Then $X = \frac{1}{3} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & -2 & 1 \\ 6 & 1 & -5 \\ -3 & 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{1}{3} \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ -7 \\ 6 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -1/3 \\ -7/3 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: Solve the following equations by the method of inversion. $x + 2y = 2, 2x + 3y = 3$. (March 2022)
answer: The matrix form is $AX=B$, where $A=\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 2 & 3 \end{pmatrix}, X=\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \end{pmatrix}, B=\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}$. The solution is $X=A^{-1}B$. $|A|=3-4=-1$. $A^{-1} = \frac{1}{-1}\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -2 \\ -2 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -3 & 2 \\ 2 & -1 \end{pmatrix}$. So, $X = \begin{pmatrix} -3 & 2 \\ 2 & -1 \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -6+6 \\ 4-3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$. Thus, $x=0, y=1$.

text: Solve the following equations by the method of reduction. $x - y + z = 4, 2x + y - 3z = 0, x + y + z = 2$. (March 2020)
answer: The augmented matrix is $\left[ \begin{array}{ccc|c} 1 & -1 & 1 & 4 \\ 2 & 1 & -3 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 & 2 \end{array} \right]$. Apply $R_2 \to R_2 - 2R_1$ and $R_3 \to R_3 - R_1$ to get $\left[ \begin{array}{ccc|c} 1 & -1 & 1 & 4 \\ 0 & 3 & -5 & -8 \\ 0 & 2 & 0 & -2 \end{array} \right]$. From $R_3$, $2y=-2 \implies y=-1$. From $R_2$, $3y-5z=-8 \implies -3-5z=-8 \implies 5z=5 \implies z=1$. From $R_1$, $x-y+z=4 \implies x-(-1)+1=4 \implies x+2=4 \implies x=2$. The solution is $x=2, y=-1, z=1$.

text: The cost of 4 dozen pencils, 3 dozen pens and 2 dozen erasers is ₹ 60. The cost of 2 dozen pencils, 4 dozen pens and 6 dozen erasers is ₹ 90 whereas the cost of 6 dozen pencils, 2 dozen pens and 3 dozen erasers is ₹ 70. Find the cost of each item per dozen by using matrices. (HSC Textbook)
answer: Let the cost per dozen of pencils, pens, and erasers be x, y, z respectively. The system of equations is: $4x+3y+2z=60$, $2x+4y+6z=90$, $6x+2y+3z=70$. In matrix form $AX=B$. Using the inversion method, we find $A^{-1}$ and then $X=A^{-1}B$. $|A|=-50$. $A^{-1} = \frac{1}{-50}\begin{pmatrix} 0 & -5 & 10 \\ 30 & 0 & -20 \\ -20 & 10 & 10 \end{pmatrix}$. $X = A^{-1}B = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ 8 \\ 8 \end{pmatrix}$. The cost of pencils is ₹5/dozen, pens is ₹8/dozen, and erasers is ₹8/dozen.

text: The inverse of a symmetric matrix is -
If $A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix}$ and $A(\text{adj }A) = kI$ then the value of k is
Construct a matrix $A = [a_{ij}]_{3 \times 2}$ whose elements are given by $a_{ij} = \frac{(i-j)^2}{5-i}$. (HSC Textbook)
If $A = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -1 \\ 3 & -2 \\ 4 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $B = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ -1 & 4 \\ -2 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$, find the matrix X such that $3A - 2B + X = I$.
answer:
From the equation, $X = I - 3A + 2B$.
$X = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix} - 3\begin{pmatrix} 2 & -1 \\ 3 & -2 \\ 4 & 1 \end{pmatrix} + 2\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 3 \\ -1 & 4 \\ -2 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$. Note: Matrix dimensions do not match for addition. Assuming a $3 \times 2$ identity matrix is not standard. Assuming the problem implies a 2x2 context and there's a typo in A and B dimensions. If A and B were 2x2, we could proceed. As stated, the operation is undefined.

text: If $A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix}$ and $B = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 5 \\ 6 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$, then $2A+B$ is:
The transpose of the matrix $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & -1 & 2 \\ 3 & 5 & 7 \\ 4 & 0 & 9 \end{pmatrix}$ is:
Find $k$ if the matrix $\begin{pmatrix} 7 & 3 \\ -2 & k \end{pmatrix}$ is singular. (March 2016)
answer:
A matrix is singular if its determinant is zero.
$|A| = (7)(k) - (3)(-2) = 7k + 6$.
Setting the determinant to zero: $7k+6=0 \implies 7k=-6 \implies k = -6/7$.

text: Apply the given elementary transformation $R_1 \leftrightarrow R_2$ on $A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$.
answer:
Applying the transformation $R_1 \leftrightarrow R_2$ means swapping the first and second rows.
$A \sim \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 3 \\ 1 & 2 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: Find the inverse of $A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 1 & 1 & 5 \\ 2 & 4 & 7 \end{pmatrix}$ by elementary row transformations. (July 2019)
answer: Start with $[A|I]$. $\left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc} 1 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 & 5 & 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 2 & 4 & 7 & 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array} \right]$. Apply $R_2 \to R_2-R_1$, $R_3 \to R_3-2R_1$ to get $\left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc} 1 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & 2 & -1 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 & -2 & 0 & 1 \end{array} \right]$. Continue with row transformations to get $[I|A^{-1}]$. The result is $A^{-1} = \begin{pmatrix} 13 & 2 & -7 \\ -3 & -1 & 2 \\ -2 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: Solve the system of equations $2x-y+z=1$, $x+2y+3z=8$, $3x+y-4z=1$ using the method of reduction. (March 2023)
answer: The augmented matrix is $\left[ \begin{array}{ccc|c} 2 & -1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 2 & 3 & 8 \\ 3 & 1 & -4 & 1 \end{array} \right]$. Swap $R_1$ and $R_2$. Apply $R_2 \to R_2 - 2R_1$, $R_3 \to R_3 - 3R_1$. Continue reducing to row echelon form. The final system yields the solution $x=1, y=2, z=1$.

text: If three numbers are added, their sum is 2. If 2 times the second number is subtracted from the sum of first and third numbers we get 8 and if three times the first number is added to the sum of second and third numbers we get 4. Find the numbers using matrices. (July 2022)
answer: Let the numbers be x, y, z. The equations are: $x+y+z=2$, $x+z-2y=8$, $3x+y+z=4$. In matrix form $AX=B$. Solve using inversion or reduction. Solution: $x=1, y=-2, z=3$.

text: If matrix $A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 4 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$ is such that $AX=I$, then X is:
Find the inverse of $\begin{pmatrix} 2 & -3 \\ 5 & 7 \end{pmatrix}$ by using elementary row transformations. (HSC Textbook)
answer: Start with $[A|I] = \left[ \begin{array}{cc|cc} 2 & -3 & 1 & 0 \\ 5 & 7 & 0 & 1 \end{array} \right]$. Apply $R_1 \to \frac{1}{2}R_1$. Then $R_2 \to R_2 - 5R_1$. Continue transformations to get $[I|A^{-1}]$. The result is $A^{-1} = \frac{1}{29}\begin{pmatrix} 7 & 3 \\ -5 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: If $A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 & 2 \\ 0 & 1 & 3 \\ 1 & 2 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$, find its inverse using elementary column transformations.
answer: Start with $\left[\begin{array}{c} A \\ I \end{array}\right]$. Apply column transformations like $C_1 \to C_1-C_2$ and so on, to transform A into I. The matrix in the lower part will be transformed into $A^{-1}$. The final result is $A^{-1} = \frac{1}{4}\begin{pmatrix} 5 & -3 & -1 \\ -3 & 1 & 3 \\ 1 & 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: The co-factor of element '4' in the matrix $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix}$ is:
Solve by reduction method: $x+y+z=6, 3x-y+3z=10, 5x+5y-4z=3$. (HSC Textbook)
answer: The augmented matrix is $\left[ \begin{array}{ccc|c} 1 & 1 & 1 & 6 \\ 3 & -1 & 3 & 10 \\ 5 & 5 & -4 & 3 \end{array} \right]$. Apply $R_2 \to R_2-3R_1$ and $R_3 \to R_3-5R_1$. Continue reducing to row echelon form. The final system gives the solution $x=1, y=2, z=3$.

text: If $A$ is a non-singular matrix of order 3, and $|A|=5$, then $|\text{adj}(A)|$ is:
Find the inverse of $A = \text{diag}[2, 3, 4]$.
answer: The matrix is $A = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 4 \end{pmatrix}$. The inverse of a diagonal matrix is the matrix of the reciprocals of the diagonal elements. Therefore, $A^{-1} = \text{diag}[1/2, 1/3, 1/4] = \begin{pmatrix} 1/2 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1/3 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1/4 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: If $A = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 2 \\ 1 & 4 \end{pmatrix}$, find the matrix B such that $AB=I$. (March 2018)
answer: The matrix B is the inverse of A. $|A| = (3)(4) - (2)(1) = 12-2=10$. $B = A^{-1} = \frac{1}{10}\text{adj}(A) = \frac{1}{10}\begin{pmatrix} 4 & -2 \\ -1 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: Apply the transformation $2C_2$ on $A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{pmatrix}$.
answer:
The transformation $2C_2$ means multiplying the second column by 2.
$A \sim \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2(2) \\ 3 & 4(2) \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 4 \\ 3 & 8 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: For a matrix $A$, if $A^2=A$, then $A$ is called:
Solve by method of inversion: $x+y+z=1, 2x+3y+2z=2, ax+ay+2az=4$. For what value of 'a' does the system have a unique solution? (HSC Textbook)
answer: The system has a unique solution if the determinant of the coefficient matrix is non-zero. $A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 3 & 2 \\ a & a & 2a \end{pmatrix}$. $|A| = 1(6a-2a) - 1(4a-2a) + 1(2a-3a) = 4a-2a-a=a$. For a unique solution, $|A| \neq 0$, so $a \neq 0$. For $a=1$, $|A|=1$. $A^{-1}$ can be found, and then $X=A^{-1}B$ gives the solution $x=2, y=-1, z=0$.

text: If $A = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -1 \\ 3 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $B = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 4 \\ -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$, find $(A+B)^T$.
answer: First find $A+B = \begin{pmatrix} 2+1 & -1+4 \\ 3-1 & 1+0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 3 \\ 2 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$. Now, find the transpose: $(A+B)^T = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 2 \\ 3 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: If A is a 3x3 matrix and $|A|=2$, then $|3A|$ is:
Find the inverse of $A = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -1 & 1 \\ -15 & 6 & -5 \\ 5 & -2 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$ using row transformations. (March 2024)
answer: Start with $[A|I]$. $\left[ \begin{array}{ccc|ccc} 3 & -1 & 1 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\ -15 & 6 & -5 & 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 5 & -2 & 2 & 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array} \right]$. Apply $R_2 \to R_2 + 5R_1$. Continue transformations to reach $[I|A^{-1}]$. The inverse is $A^{-1} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0 & -1 \\ 5 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: Show that the matrix $A = \frac{1}{3}\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 & -2 \\ -2 & 2 & -1 \end{pmatrix}$ is orthogonal.
answer: A matrix A is orthogonal if $AA^T = I$. First find $A^T = \frac{1}{3}\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & -2 \\ 2 & 1 & 2 \\ 2 & -2 & -1 \end{pmatrix}$. Now compute $AA^T = \frac{1}{9}\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 & -2 \\ -2 & 2 & -1 \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & -2 \\ 2 & 1 & 2 \\ 2 & -2 & -1 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{1}{9}\begin{pmatrix} 9 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 9 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 9 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = I$. Since $AA^T=I$, the matrix is orthogonal.

text: Find the values of x, y, z if $\begin{pmatrix} x-y & z \\ 2x-y & w \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 4 \\ 0 & 5 \end{pmatrix}$.
answer: By equality of matrices, we equate corresponding elements. $z=4, w=5$. We have a system of two linear equations: $x-y=-1$ and $2x-y=0$. Subtracting the first from the second gives $(2x-y)-(x-y) = 0-(-1) \implies x=1$. Substituting $x=1$ into the first equation gives $1-y=-1 \implies y=2$. Solution: $x=1, y=2, z=4, w=5$.

text: If $A$ is a square matrix such that $A^2=I$, then $(A-I)^2 + (A+I)^2 - 6A$ is equal to:
If $A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$, show that $A^2-3A-3I$ is a null matrix.
answer:
$A^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 4 \\ 4 & 5 \end{pmatrix}$.
$3A = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 6 \\ 6 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$.
$3I = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$.
$A^2-3A-3I = \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 4 \\ 4 & 5 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 6 \\ 6 & 3 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$. The expression seems incorrect, as it doesn't result in a null matrix. There might be a typo in the question, perhaps it should be $A^2-2A-3I$.

text: Find the inverse of $\begin{pmatrix} \sec\theta & 	an\theta \\ 	an\theta & \sec\theta \end{pmatrix}$.
answer: Let $A$ be the matrix. $|A| = \sec^2\theta - \tan^2\theta = 1$. The adjoint is adj(A) = $\begin{pmatrix} \sec\theta & -\tan\theta \\ -\tan\theta & \sec\theta \end{pmatrix}$. Since the determinant is 1, the inverse is equal to the adjoint: $A^{-1} = \begin{pmatrix} \sec\theta & -\tan\theta \\ -\tan\theta & \sec\theta \end{pmatrix}$.

text: If a matrix A is both symmetric and skew-symmetric, then A is a:
Solve by reduction method: $x+3y+3z=16, x+4y+4z=21, x+3y+4z=19$. (March 2019)
answer: The augmented matrix is $\left[ \begin{array}{ccc|c} 1 & 3 & 3 & 16 \\ 1 & 4 & 4 & 21 \\ 1 & 3 & 4 & 19 \end{array} \right]$. Apply $R_2 \to R_2 - R_1$ and $R_3 \to R_3 - R_1$. This gives $\left[ \begin{array}{ccc|c} 1 & 3 & 3 & 16 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 & 5 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 & 3 \end{array} \right]$. Back substitution gives $z=3$. From $R_2$: $y+z=5 \implies y+3=5 \implies y=2$. From $R_1$: $x+3y+3z=16 \implies x+6+9=16 \implies x=1$. Solution: $x=1, y=2, z=3$.

text: Find the inverse of $A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & -2 \\ -1 & 3 & 0 \\ 0 & -2 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$ by using elementary row transformations. (July 2018)
answer: Start with $[A|I]$. Perform row operations to transform A into I. The matrix on the right will become $A^{-1}$. The inverse is $A^{-1} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 2 & 6 \\ 1 & 1 & 2 \\ 2 & 2 & 5 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: The matrix $\begin{pmatrix} 0 & -5 & 8 \\ 5 & 0 & 12 \\ -8 & -12 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$ is a:
If $A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 2 \\ -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$, find $(A^T)^T$.
answer: First find the transpose $A^T = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 3 & -1 \\ 2 & 2 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$. Now, find the transpose of $A^T$. $(A^T)^T = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 2 \\ -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$. We observe that $(A^T)^T = A$.

text: If $A = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -1 \\ 2 & 4 \end{pmatrix}$, $B = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ -3 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$, find $(A+B)^T$ and verify that $(A+B)^T = A^T+B^T$.
answer: $A+B = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 1 \\ -1 & 4 \end{pmatrix}$, so $(A+B)^T = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & -1 \\ 1 & 4 \end{pmatrix}$. Also, $A^T = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 2 \\ -1 & 4 \end{pmatrix}$ and $B^T = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & -3 \\ 2 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$. $A^T+B^T = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & -1 \\ 1 & 4 \end{pmatrix}$. The property is verified.

text: If A is a 2x2 matrix such that $A^2-4A+4I=0$, then $A^{-1}$ is equal to:
Solve by inversion: $x+y+z=3, x-y+2z=2, x+2y-z=2$.
answer: Matrix form is $AX=B$. $|A|=7$. $A^{-1} = \frac{1}{7}\begin{pmatrix} -3 & 3 & 3 \\ 3 & -2 & -1 \\ 3 & -1 & -2 \end{pmatrix}$. $X = A^{-1}B = \frac{1}{7}\begin{pmatrix} -3 & 3 & 3 \\ 3 & -2 & -1 \\ 3 & -1 & -2 \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 2 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix} = \frac{1}{7}\begin{pmatrix} 3 \\ 3 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 3/7 \\ 3/7 \\ 3/7 \end{pmatrix}$. This solution seems unusual. Rechecking determinant: $1(-1-4)-1(-1-2)+1(2-(-1))= -5+3+3=1$. The determinant is 1. Recalculating adj(A) and inverse gives solution $x=1, y=1, z=1$.

text: Find the inverse of $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 4 \\ 3 & 1 & 0 \\ -1 & 2 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$ if it exists.
answer: Let $A$ be the matrix. $|A|=1(1)-2(3)+4(7) = 1-6+28=23$. Since the determinant is non-zero, the inverse exists. The adjoint is adj(A) = $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 6 & -4 \\ -3 & 5 & 12 \\ 7 & -4 & -5 \end{pmatrix}$. So $A^{-1} = \frac{1}{23}\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 6 & -4 \\ -3 & 5 & 12 \\ 7 & -4 & -5 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: If $A=\begin{pmatrix} 2 & 2 \\ -3 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$ and $B=\begin{pmatrix} 0 & -1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$ then $(B^{-1}A^{-1})^{-1}$ is equal to
Express the matrix $A = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & -2 \\ 3 & -5 \end{pmatrix}$ as a sum of a symmetric and a skew-symmetric matrix. (HSC Textbook)
answer:
Any square matrix A can be written as $A = P+Q$ where $P=\frac{1}{2}(A+A^T)$ is symmetric and $Q=\frac{1}{2}(A-A^T)$ is skew-symmetric.
$A^T = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 3 \\ -2 & -5 \end{pmatrix}$.
$P = \frac{1}{2}(\begin{pmatrix} 4 & -2 \\ 3 & -5 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 3 \\ -2 & -5 \end{pmatrix}) = \frac{1}{2}\begin{pmatrix} 8 & 1 \\ 1 & -10 \end{pmatrix}$.
$Q = \frac{1}{2}(\begin{pmatrix} 4 & -2 \\ 3 & -5 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 3 \\ -2 & -5 \end{pmatrix}) = \frac{1}{2}\begin{pmatrix} 0 & -5 \\ 5 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$.
$A = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 1/2 \\ 1/2 & -5 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} 0 & -5/2 \\ 5/2 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: If $A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 0 \\ -1 & 1 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$ and $B = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 3 & 2 \\ -1 & 2 & 0 \\ 1 & 2 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$, find $(AB)^T$.
answer: First find the product $AB = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 7 & 2 \\ -3 & 5 & 0 \\ 3 & 9 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$. Now find the transpose of the product: $(AB)^T = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -3 & 3 \\ 7 & 5 & 9 \\ 2 & 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: The existence of the inverse of a square matrix A is confirmed if:
Find the inverse of $A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 1 \\ 3 & 2 & 3 \\ 1 & 1 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$ by elementary column transformations.
answer: Start with $\left[\begin{array}{c} A \\ I \end{array}\right]$. Perform column operations to transform A into I. The matrix in the lower part will become $A^{-1}$. The final result is $A^{-1} = \frac{1}{-2}\begin{pmatrix} 1 & -3 & 4 \\ -3 & 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 & -4 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: Solve the equations $x+y=1$ and $3x+2y=4$ by the method of reduction.
answer: The augmented matrix is $\left[ \begin{array}{cc|c} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 3 & 2 & 4 \end{array} \right]$. Apply $R_2 \to R_2 - 3R_1$. $\left[ \begin{array}{cc|c} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 0 & -1 & 1 \end{array} \right]$. This gives the system $x+y=1$ and $-y=1$. From the second equation, $y=-1$. Substituting into the first, $x-1=1 \implies x=2$. The solution is $(2, -1)$.

text: If $A$ and $B$ are invertible matrices, then which of the following is not true?
If $A = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ 4 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$, find $A^2$. Is A invertible?
answer: $A^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ 4 & 2 \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ 4 & 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 8 & 4 \\ 16 & 8 \end{pmatrix} = 4A$. To check if A is invertible, we find its determinant: $|A| = (2)(2) - (1)(4) = 4-4=0$. Since the determinant is 0, A is not invertible.

text: Find the inverse of the matrix $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$.
answer: This is the identity matrix, $I$. The inverse of the identity matrix is the identity matrix itself. $I^{-1}=I$.

text: The element in the 2nd row and 3rd column of the inverse of the matrix $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & -3 \\ 0 & -2 & 0 \\ -2 & -2 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$ is:
If $A = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 1 & 5 \end{pmatrix}$, find $A^2 - 7A + 7I$.
answer: This relates to the Cayley-Hamilton theorem. The characteristic equation is $|A-\lambda I|=0$, which is $(2-\lambda)(5-\lambda)-3=0 \implies \lambda^2-7\lambda+7=0$. By the theorem, A satisfies this equation, so $A^2-7A+7I=0$. Thus the result is a null matrix $\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: If $A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$, find a polynomial in A which is equal to the null matrix.
answer: The characteristic equation is $|A-\lambda I|=0$, which is $(1-\lambda)^2-4=0 \implies \lambda^2-2\lambda-3=0$. By the Cayley-Hamilton theorem, the matrix A satisfies this polynomial. So, $A^2-2A-3I=0$. The polynomial is $P(A) = A^2-2A-3I$.

text: A square matrix $A$ is called orthogonal if:
Find the inverse of $A = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 4 \end{pmatrix}$ by adjoint method.
answer: $|A| = 24$. The co-factor matrix is $\begin{pmatrix} 12 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 8 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 6 \end{pmatrix}$. The adjoint is the same since the co-factor matrix is diagonal. $A^{-1} = \frac{1}{24} \begin{pmatrix} 12 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 8 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 6 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1/2 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1/3 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1/4 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: If $A$ and $B$ are matrices of order 3 and $|A|=5, |B|=3$, then find $|3AB|$.
answer: Using the properties of determinants, $|kC| = k^n|C|$ and $|AB|=|A||B|$. Here, n=3. So, $|3AB| = 3^3 |A||B| = 27(5)(3) = 405$.

text: What kind of matrix is $\begin{pmatrix} 4 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 4 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 4 \end{pmatrix}$?
Construct a $2 \times 3$ matrix $A=[a_{ij}]$ where $a_{ij} = i - 3j$.
If $A = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 1 \\ -1 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$, show that $A^2 - 5A + 7I = 0$. Hence find $A^{-1}$. (March 2019)
answer: $A^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 8 & 5 \\ -5 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$. $A^2-5A+7I = \begin{pmatrix} 8 & 5 \\ -5 & 3 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 15 & 5 \\ -5 & 10 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} 7 & 0 \\ 0 & 7 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$. To find $A^{-1}$, multiply the equation by $A^{-1}$: $A - 5I + 7A^{-1}=0 \implies 7A^{-1} = 5I - A = \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 0 \\ 0 & 5 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 1 \\ -1 & 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -1 \\ 1 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$. So $A^{-1} = \frac{1}{7}\begin{pmatrix} 2 & -1 \\ 1 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: In the matrix $\begin{pmatrix} 2 & 5 & 19 & -7 \\ 35 & -2 & 5/2 & 12 \\ \sqrt{3} & 1 & -5 & 17 \end{pmatrix}$, the element $a_{23}$ is:
Find the values of $a, b, c$ from the equation: $\begin{pmatrix} a-b & 2a+c \\ 2a-b & 3c+d \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 5 \\ 0 & 13 \end{pmatrix}$.
answer: By equality of matrices: $a-b=-1$, $2a-b=0$, $2a+c=5$, $3c+d=13$. From the first two equations, $a=1, b=2$. From the third, $2(1)+c=5 \implies c=3$. From the fourth, $3(3)+d=13 \implies d=4$. Solution: $a=1, b=2, c=3, d=4$.

text: If $A$ is a square matrix, then $A - A^T$ is a:
answer: Let $P = A-A^T$. Then $P^T = (A-A^T)^T = A^T - (A^T)^T = A^T - A = -(A-A^T) = -P$. Since $P^T = -P$, the matrix $A-A^T$ is a skew-symmetric matrix.

text: Total number of possible matrices of order 3 × 3 with each entry 2 or 0 is:
Find the inverse of $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 2 & 3 & 1 \\ 3 & 1 & 2 \end{pmatrix}$ by the adjoint method. (March 2018)
answer: Let $A$ be the matrix. $|A|=1(6-1)-2(4-3)+3(2-9) = 5-2-21=-18$. The adjoint matrix is $\text{adj}(A) = \begin{pmatrix} 5 & -1 & -7 \\ -1 & -7 & 5 \\ -7 & 5 & -1 \end{pmatrix}$. So, $A^{-1} = -\frac{1}{18} \begin{pmatrix} 5 & -1 & -7 \\ -1 & -7 & 5 \\ -7 & 5 & -1 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: For a matrix $A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 6 & 7 \end{pmatrix}$, verify that $(A^T)^T=A$.
answer: $A^T = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 6 \\ 5 & 7 \end{pmatrix}$. Taking the transpose again gives $(A^T)^T = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 5 \\ 6 & 7 \end{pmatrix}$, which is equal to A. Verified.

text: A matrix which is not a square matrix is called a:
Find $X$ and $Y$ if $X+Y = \begin{pmatrix} 5 & 2 \\ 0 & 9 \end{pmatrix}$ and $X-Y = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 6 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}$.
answer: Adding the two equations: $2X = \begin{pmatrix} 8 & 8 \\ 0 & 8 \end{pmatrix}$, so $X = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 4 \\ 0 & 4 \end{pmatrix}$. Subtracting the second from the first: $2Y = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -4 \\ 0 & 10 \end{pmatrix}$, so $Y = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & -2 \\ 0 & 5 \end{pmatrix}$.

text: If $A = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -2 \\ 4 & -2 \end{pmatrix}$, find k so that $A^2=kA-2I$.
answer: $A^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & -2 \\ 4 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$. The equation is $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & -2 \\ 4 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = k\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -2 \\ 4 & -2 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0 \\ 0 & 2 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 3k-2 & -2k \\ 4k & -2k-2 \end{pmatrix}$. Equating elements, from the top left, $1=3k-2 \implies 3k=3 \implies k=1$.

text: If $A$ is an invertible matrix of order 2, then det($A^{-1}$) is equal to
Find the inverse of $A = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & -2 & 3 \\ 0 & -1 & 4 \\ -2 & 2 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$ by using elementary column transformations.
answer: Start with $\left[\begin{array}{c} A \\ I \end{array}\right]$. Perform column operations to transform A into I. The matrix in the lower part will become $A^{-1}$. The final result is $A^{-1} = \begin{pmatrix} -9 & 8 & -5 \\ -8 & 7 & -4 \\ -2 & 2 & -1 \end{pmatrix}$.
